Title: Find the Poincare Dual of a ray in $\mathbb{R}^2-\{0\}$
Content: This is example-exercise 5.16 in Bott and Tu (which I'm independently reading through.)  The problem states: Let $M=\mathbb{R}^2-\{0\}$, and $X\subseteq M$ be the closed submanifold $\{(x,0):x>0\}$.  Show that the Poincare dual of $X$ is $d\theta/2\pi$. My attempt at a solution:  We want to show that for all $\omega\in H_c^1(M)$, $\int_X\omega=\int_{M}\omega\wedge d\theta/2\pi$.  So let $\omega=fdr+gd\theta$ be a closed 1-form on $M$ with compact support.  It follows that $f$ and $g$ have compact support, and $d\omega=0$ so $\partial f/\partial \theta=\partial g/\partial r$ everywhere on $M$. We want to use this to show that $\int_X\omega=\int_{0}^\infty f(r,0)dr=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{0}^{2\pi}\int_{0}^\infty f(r,\theta)drd\theta$.  So if for some reason $f$ doesn't depend on $\theta$ then we are done.  But I don't see how to show this, much less how to use the closed assumption any further.  Any hints/suggestions/errors in my work?
AcceptedAnswer:
There are fancier ways to do this, which you'll learn eventually: If a compact group $G$ acts on $M$, then any closed $k$-form $\omega$ on $M$ is cohomologous to a $G$-invariant closed $k$-form $\tilde\omega$ on $M$ (i.e., $\omega-\tilde\omega = d\eta$ for some $k-1$-form $\eta$). But let's just do this bare-hands here. Consider 
$$\frac d{d\theta}\int_0^\infty f(r,\theta)dr = \int_0^\infty \frac{\partial f}{\partial \theta}dr = \int_0^\infty \frac{\partial g}{\partial r}dr = 0,$$
since $g$ has compact support in $M$. So, evidently,
$$\int_0^\infty f(r,\theta)dr = \int_0^\infty f(r,0)dr \text{ for all } \theta\in [0,2\pi],$$
and your result follows.

Original_Problem:
Assumption: 
$M = \mathbb{R}^2 \setminus \{0\}$,
$X \subseteq M$ is the closed submanifold $\{(x, 0) : x > 0\}$,
$\omega$ is a closed 1-form in $H_c^1(M)$,
$\omega$ has compact support,
$\omega$ can be expressed in polar coordinates as $\omega = f\,dr + g\,d\theta$,
$f$ and $g$ have compact support,
$\partial g / \partial r = \partial f / \partial \theta$ (due to $d\omega = 0$).
Problem:
Show that the Poincaré dual of $X$ is $d\theta / 2\pi$, i.e., prove that for all $\omega \in H_c^1(M)$,  
$$\int_X \omega = \int_M \omega \wedge \frac{d\theta}{2\pi}.$$
